data.title: Collin County, Texas Relocation Guide
data.meta_description: Collin County, TX Ultimate Relocation Guide. Moving to Texas? Explore facts and info about Collin County, TX. Call 214.940.8149 Oleg Sedletsky Your Collin County, TX Realtor®.
data.text:
Is Collin County growing?

There’s no denying that Collin County is growing. As of the 2020 census, the population was 1,064,465. And as of 2021, the estimated population is 1,109,462. That’s an increase of nearly 5%. But what does that mean for those who live in Collin County? Well, for starters, it means that there are more people moving to Collin County than ever before. And that’s not surprising given the many reasons why people choose to relocate here. From the great schools to the abundance of jobs, there’s a lot to love about Collin County. And with the population continuing to grow, it’s only going to get better.

As of 2020 cencus population was 1,064,465

As of 2021, the estimated population was 1,109,462

Is Collin County Urban or rural?

If you’re thinking about moving to Collin County, you might be wondering if it’s an urban or rural area. According to Census Bureau data, the answer is mostly urban. 94.76% of the county is considered urban, while only 5.24% is rural. So if you’re looking for a big city feel, Collin County is a great place to call home. But buyer beware – with such a high percentage of the county being urban, competition for housing can be fierce. So if you’re thinking about relocating to Collin County, start your search early and be prepared to act fast when you find the perfect place to call home.

Urban vs Rural in Collin County

Percent Urban: 94.76

Percent Rural: 5.24

Texas Property Tax Exemptions – Property Tax Assistance

Texas offers “Homestead Exemption” to home owners. The Homestead Exemption provides an exemption from property taxes on a home. Homestead exemptions remove part of your home’s value from taxation, so they lower your taxes. For example, your home is appraised at $100,000, and you qualify for a $25,000 exemption (this is the amount mandated for school districts), you will pay school taxes on the home as if it was worth only $75,000. Taxing units have the option to offer a separate exemption of up to 20 percent of the total value.

A homestead can include up to 20 acres, if the land is owned by the homeowner and used for a purpose related to the residential use of the homestead. You can own multiple properties in Texas but only your primary home will be designated as homestead.

You may apply for homestead exemptions on your principal residence only.

MORE from Texas Comptroller website: https://comptroller.texas.gov/taxes/property-tax/exemptions/residence-faq.php

As your Texas Relocation Specialist and Dallas-Fort Worth Real Estate Expert REALTOR® I will help you to apply for your Homestead Exemption

When it comes to the overall school ratings in Collin County, TX, it can be subjective depending on what you are looking for specifically. Therefore, when you plan to relocate to Collin County, TX, I advise doing your homework and conducting thorough research on the schools.

Please consider the following resources:

GreatSchools

GreatSchools is the leading national nonprofit empowering parents to unlock educational opportunities for their child.

GreatSchools’ trusted ratings and school information help parents find the right school for their family and improve schools in their communities. The thousands of articles, tips and interactive tools help parents support their child’s learning and well being every day.

Families, community leaders and policy-makers turn to GreatSchools for the school information they need to guide children to great futures.

Website: https://www.greatschools.org/texas/

Niche.com

Niche is the market leader in connecting colleges and schools with students and families. With in-depth profiles on every school and college in America, over 140 million reviews and ratings, and powerful search and data tools, Niche helps millions of students and families find and enroll in the right school for them. For schools, school districts, and communities, Niche’s platform, data, and services help thousands of schools recruit and enroll more best-fit students.

Website: https://www.niche.com/k12/search/best-schools/c/collin-county-tx/

Is Collin County TX a good place to live?

Collin County is a thriving community that offers its residents a high quality of life. The county is home to a number of large cities, including Plano, Frisco, McKinney, and Allen, and is just a short drive from Dallas. With plenty of shopping, dining, and entertainment options, Collin County has something for everyone. And for those who are looking for a more laid-back lifestyle, the county also boasts several small towns and rural areas. Whether you’re looking for an urban or rural setting, Collin County has it all. So if you’re thinking about relocating to the area, be sure to check out Collin County – you won’t be disappointed.
